content:
Even though your clash has been approved, could you please follow up the remaining points in my original comment?

Goal
* Please format all instances of "n", "l", "m", "h" and "x" as {{constants}}.

Constraints
* Please rewrite the first constraint as:
1 ≤ length of [[track]] ≤ 100

* Please format "n", "l", "m", "h" and "x" as {{constants}}.

Thanks.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear and fun.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: nice contribution, should be playable in shortest mode

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: W proposition really cool
I agree with Rodder that this clash would be good (as reverse and shortest as well) and I think getting rid of the third bullet point would make it better.

Enjoyed this clash. However, I did not understand the need for the statement "move them to the end of the track before sorting". Without doing this step, I still get all correct answers. 5DN1L has already addressed this, but I feel that you should just remove it entirely instead of changing the output of the test cases. Nonetheless, it was still a great puzzle. However, I feel that if you change that one line, this puzzle would make a perfect reverse and shortest clash as well. But still great puzzle!

General
* The "move to the end before sorting" rule has no actual effect in the provided solution. Since all notes (both `fixed_track` and `glitches`) are concatenated and then fully sorted, their original order is lost. Even changing 3 to another integer (e.g. 9999) in your solution produces the same final output.

To resolve this, either (for both the statement and the solution):

• remove this step entirely, or

• modify the sorting step to apply only to the non-glitched notes, and then prepend or append (depends on what you want) the glitched notes.

Title & Goal
* Please use a generic name (e.g. "Rapper CG") instead of referencing a specific artist.

Goal
* Please format "n", "l", "m", "h" and "x" as {{constants}}.

Input
* Please replace "settings" with "effects" to match the wording used in the Goal section.

Constraints
* Please rewrite the first constraint as:
1 ≤ length of [[track]] ≤ 100

(Note that 200 is changed to 100 because the longest string contains 37 characters only.)

* Please format "n", "l", "m", "h" and "x" as {{constants}}.

* Please add "in [[track]]" after "used".

Thanks.

As a reverse puzzle, it would require quite a number of examples and I am not sure how long it would take to figure out that an odd/even number of notes matters. Perhaps passing the number of notes as an integer would help.

I agree that shortest would work without the third rule.
